contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox rebbe | title = Sigeter Rebbe | image =Teie3.jpg | caption =The headstones over the graves of Rabbi Yekusiel Yehuda Teitelbaum and his wife in Sighet | term =1858–1883 | full name = Yekusiel Yehuda Teitelbaum | main work = Yetev Lev | predecessor =Elozor Nison Teitelbaum | successor =[[Chananya Yom Tov Lipa Teitelbaum]] | spouse1 =Ruchl Ashkenazi | issue1 =Avrohom Aharon<br/>Chananya Yomtov Lipa<br/>Moshe Yosef<br/>Elya Btzalel<br/>three daughters | spouse2 = | issue2 = | spouse3 = | issue3 = | dynastyname = | father = Elozor Nison Teitelbaum | date of burial = | place of burial =[[Sighet]] |}} Rabbi '''Yekusiel Yehuda Teitelbaum''' (1808–1883), known as the ''Yetev Lev'', was a [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic]] ''[[Rebbe]]'' in [[Austria-Hungary]]. ==Early life and education== He was the son of Rabbi [[Elazar Nison Teitelbaum]], rabbi of [[Drohobych|Drubitsh]], who was the son of the ''[[Yismach Moshe]]'' (Rabbi Moshe Teitelbaum. Renowned [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] rabbis are sometimes known by the titles of their religious works) of [[Sátoraljaújhely|Ujhel]], [[Hungary]]. ==Career== After his studies, Yekusiel Yehuda, also known by his [[Yiddish]] equivalent names as Zalman Leib, was appointed as the rabbi of [[Stropkov]] (1833). He moved to Ujhel (1841) and then to Drubitsh (1856). When the Jewish community in the city of [[Sighet]], [[Hungary]], was looking for a new rabbi, he was invited by the heads of the community<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hebrewbooks.org/pdfpager.aspx?req=1202&st=&pgnum=7|title=בית סיגט ואוהל|work=HebrewBooks.org|language=[[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]|accessdate=Feb/14/13}}</ref> and was appointed to that post in 1858. He also served as a hasidic ''rebbe'' and became known as the ''rebbe of [[Ujhel-Siget (Hasidic dynasty)|Siget]]''. == Family life == Yekusiel Yehuda Tetelbaum married Ruchl, a daughter of Rabbi Moshe Dovid Ashkenazi of [[Toltsva]] and his wife. Their sons were [[Chananya Yom Tov Lipa Teitelbaum|Chananya Yomtov Lipa]], author of ''Kedishas Yomtov'', who succeeded his father in Siget; Avrohom Aharon, who became the rabbi of [[Kolbasov]]; Moshe Yosef, the rabbi of Ujhel; and Eliyohu Betsalel, rabbi of Tetsh ([[Tyachiv]], Ukraine) (''see: [[Tetsh (Hasidic dynasty)]]''). Yekusiel and Ruchl Teitelbaum also had three daughters. Among the descendants of Yekusiel and Ruchl was their grandson Rabbi [[Joel Teitelbaum]], the rebbe of [[Satmar (Hasidic dynasty)|Satmar]], who emigrated to the [[United States]] after [[the Holocaust]]. Reb Boruch of [[Gorlice|Gorlitz]], son of the ''Divrei Chaim'' of [[Sanz (Hasidic dynasty)|Sanz]], married one of their daughters. A great-grandson of Teitelbaum's from that marriage was Rabbi [[Yekusiel Yehudah Halberstam]] of [[Klausenburg (Hasidic dynasty)|Klausenberg]]. == Teachings and published works == Yekusiel Yehuda was the author of ''Yetev Lev'', a Hasidic commentary on the [[Torah]], which he originally published anonymously; ''Yetev Ponim'' on the [[Jewish holiday]]s, and the [[responsa]] ''Avnei Tsedek''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hebrewbooks.org/659|title=Avnei Tzedek|year=1885|work=HebrewBooks.org|location=[[Lvov]]|accessdate=Feb/14/13}}</ref> and ''Rav Tuv''. == Sources == {{cite book|title= שם ושארית Shem uSheirith|author=Levi Grossman|location=Jerusalem|year=1943}} {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-bef|before=Moshe Schonfeld}} {{s-ttl|title=Chief Rabbi of [[Stropkov]] |years=1833–1841}} {{s-aft|after=[[Hayyim Joseph Gottlieb of Stropkov|Chayim Yosef Gottlieb]]}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Teitelbaum, Yekusiel Yehuda | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Hasidic raabi | DATE OF BIRTH = 1808 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1883 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Teitelbaum, Yekusiel Yehuda}} [[Category:Hasidic rebbes]] [[Category:1808 births]] [[Category:1883 deaths]] [[Category:Hasidic rabbis in Europe]]
